question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
5. The function $e^{i\pi x}$ for x $\varepsilon$ {[}0, 1{]} can be
expanded in a Fourier series

$e^{i\pi x}$ = $\sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }c _{n} e^{2\pi inx}$

(a) Caculate $c_{0}$ and $c_{1}$. Simplify as much as possible. Recall
$\int e^{iax} dx = \frac{e^{iax}}{ia} + C$ for any a $\neq$ 0.
sols:
We have $\displaystyle f(x) = e^{i\pi x}$ and
$\displaystyle T = 1 - 0 = 1$. Then

\begin{align*}
c_{0} &= \frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{1}e^{-2\pi inx}f(x)dx\\
&= \int_{0}^{1}e^{0}e^{i\pi x}dx\\
&= \frac{1}{i\pi }e^{i\pi x}|_{0}^{1}\\
&= \frac{1}{i\pi }(e^{i\pi }-1) + C\\
&= \frac{1}{i\pi }(\cos(\pi ) + i\sin(\pi )-1) + C\\
&= -\frac{2}{i\pi } + C
\end{align*}

and

\begin{align*}
c_{1} &= \frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{1}e^{-2\pi inx}f(x)dx\\
&= \int_{0}^{1}e^{-2i\pi x}e^{i\pi x}dx\\
&= \int_{0}^{1}e^{-i\pi x}dx\\
&= -\frac{1}{i\pi }e^{-i\pi x}|_{0}^{1}\\
&= \frac{1}{i\pi }(1-e^{-i\pi }) + C\\
&= \frac{1}{i\pi }(1-\cos(-\pi ) - i\sin(-\pi )) + C\\
&= \frac{2}{i\pi } + C
\end{align*}
